2.33 p.m.

    

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1960 (Cont.)


    Head 22 -

    The Chairman: I do not know whether the guillotine fell when the Member for Farrer Park had completed his speech on his amendment. If so, I will propose the Question.

    The Question is, "That the total sum to be allocated for Head 22 be reduced by $100."

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park) gestured.

    The Chairman: The Member had not completed?

    Mr Rajah: I had not completed.

    The Chairman: I beg his pardon. I understood the Member to say he had. Well, that cancels the Question proposed. Mr Rajah?

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I misunderstood your question.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, at the moment of adjournment yesterday, I was speaking on item (1) of sub-head 58 "Confidential Stenographer". There is a sum of $11,700 provided for this post for the year 1960, whereas for the year 1959 provision was for $7,800. I have searched throughout the Budget Estimates for the pay for Confidential Stenographers, and I find that even the sum of $7,800 is high for a Confidential Stenographer as compared with the pay of such other persons throughout the various Departments.

    There is a substantial increase from $7,800 to $11,700. Could the Minister please explain why it is that the post, which is already more highly paid than those of most other Confidential Stenographers, needs such a substantial increase for 1960?

Column: 1001



    The other point on the Head, Mr Speaker, Sir, is "Manager, $24,000". I understand that the person who is holding this appointment is also Chairman of the Central Provident Fund Board. Under the provisions of that Ordinance an allowance is payable to the Chairman. Could the Minister say whether an allowance is, in fact, now being paid to the Chairman of the Central Provident Fund Board?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I must commend the Member for Farrer Park on the assiduity with which he has scrutinised the Estimates. What he said about the pay of Confidential Stenographers is substantially correct. The post against (iii) of item (1) of sub-head 58 is at present vacant, and the Singapore Industrial Promotion Board has temporarily loaned the services of an Executive Officer (Secretary) from the Ministry of National Development. To regularise the position in 1960, it is intended to second to the Board an Executive Officer with experience in Government procedure and accounting to relieve the Manager of his more routine functions, and to assist the Office Assistant in the administration of his office. The provision, therefore, includes the salary of this Executive Officer, a book-keeping allowance and his pension contributions for the period of his secondment. The salary will be about $8,000 per annum, the book-keeping allowance will be $100 per month (or $1,200 per annum), and the pension contributions about $2,000.

    As regards his second query, the answer is yes.

    Mr Rajah: Do I understand, Mr Speaker, Sir, that in respect of what are known as Temporary Staff, an Executive Officer is being brought into that section as a Permanent Officer, and because of his present emoluments, he has to be paid that sum of money set out in the 1960 Budget?

    On the second point of Manager-

    The Chairman: Order. Perhaps for the convenience of Members, I think we could deal first with the Confidential Stenographer.

Column: 1002



    Mr Rajah: Is it desirable to have a Permanent Officer in such a place, particularly when the whole setup of this Board is in a state of flux and nothing definite is known as to what the Board is doing or about to do? When a manager was appointed to this Board, a large amount of publicity was given to this appointment and a statement was made that a number of things were going to be done and achieved. So far, Mr Speaker, we have heard nothing of the doings or the achievements of this Board. Therefore, I fail to see why it is necessary to have such a highly qualified officer, paid this salary in the Board.

    The Chairman: Dr Goh. On "Confidential Stenographer".

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is very necessary to have the officer described on the Board. Members will know that it is the intention of Government to wind up the affairs of the Board as soon as the new Economic Development Board is established. The process of winding up will entail a considerable amount of work, such as finalising of accounts, making lists of assets and liabilities and, of course, there is a fair amount of work still to be done in connection with preliminary legislation setting up the Economic Development Board. As I said, it is not expected that the Industrial Promotion Board will last throughout the whole of the year, and therefore the secondment of this officer to this post will be really for a duration of a few months.

    Mr Rajah: May I proceed with the question on the Manager?

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Rajah: Could the Minister please inform the House the quantum of the allowance paid to the Chairman of the Central Provident Fund Board, and whether it is desirable that he should be paid these two sums of money for the work which he is doing probably during the same working time? I would submit to the Minister that in stringent times such as these, and even if they were not stringent times, it would not be very desirable

Column: 1003

to have him hold this post of Manager at $24,000 per annum, and at the same time be permitted to draw an allowance for some other post.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The man is really doing work in two capacities and I see no objection whatsoever to his receiving the allowances and remuneration of these two posts. He is not prevented under existing legislation from doing so, and the Government will not have the power to withhold the allowances from him. It is only a matter of whether he himself would voluntarily wish to relinquish the allowance as Chairman of the Central Provident Fund Board.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has not yet told the House what allowances he, in fact, is drawing. Might I remind the Finance Minister that it is not obligatory on the part of Government to pay the Chairman any sums of money by way of an allowance? I believe the Ordinance says "may".

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: If the Member for Farrer Park feels very strongly about it, I will look into the position and consider his proposals on its merits.

    Mr Rajah: In view of the Minister's statement, Mr Speaker, may I be given leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 22 be reduced by $100.

    On page 201 of the Estimates, just under sub-head 27, there appear the following words:- 

Contribution under       Approved

  section 23 of the     Estimates   Estimated

  Singapore                1959        1960

  Improvement            $850,000

  Ordinance


For the 1960 Estimates, there is no provision. Under section 23 of the Singapore Improvement Ordinance, it is a statutory obligation on the part of Government to provide the Singapore Improvement Trust with that amount of money which

Column: 1004

the Trust itself collects as an Improvement Rate. Now, there is an item before this House which will seek the leave of the Assembly to levy that rate. Could I ask the Minister why the contribution from Government to the Singapore Improvement Trust for the year 1960 is absent from his financial proposals?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, the answer is that in 1960 there will be no Singapore Improvement Trust.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am surprised at the answer, because there is before this House a motion which seeks to levy an Improvement Rate of 2 per cent on all properties throughout the Island and to hand it over to the Trust in the year 1960. Am I to understand from the Minister that, at the proper moment, the motion will be withdrawn?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Trust now exists. An Improvement Rate must, as a matter of formality, be approved by the Assembly this year, if we were to levy this Rate at all. But in the case of the entry in the Estimates, this is another matter. As I said, at the appropriate time, if possible, we will, either by amending legislation or subsidiary legislation, make the transfer of such funds to the appropriate housing authority.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have got the information I was seeking. May I have leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $26,094,780 for Head 22 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 1004



    Head 25 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 25 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 2*.
*An identical amendment also stood in the name of Mr A. P. Rajah.


    Under sub-head 2 there is provision for Contribution and Charitable Allowances to the sum of $25,000 for the Ministry of Culture. Under the main Head, all charitable allowances and contributions have been itemised except for the

Column: 1005

Ministry of Culture. Will the Minister please give some indication as to the organisations which will enjoy the benefit of this vote under Culture?

    Furthermore, Sir, under Head 40 - Ministry of Culture - on page 289 of the Estimates, there is a provision of $80,000 under sub-head 11 for the "Promotion of Cultural Matters". Sir, since these two items are almost the same, should not these two votes come under one heading?

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, the item is headed "Contribution and Charitable Allowances". My thought on the Ministry of Culture was that it was not interested in charitable institutions but was formed to further culture.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Cairnhill might, I think, have drawn the attention of the House to sub-head 3 under Head 25. You will note that a number of names have been listed. These refer to funds and various organisations which were to receive in 1959 contributions from the Government. It is proposed next year to make a review of contributions payable to societies and associations such as these, and it is thought that the most appropriate Ministry to do so would be the Ministry of Culture.

    It is not possible at this stage to list in detail the different organisations which would qualify for contributions, because they have yet to make applications and these applications have yet to be assessed by the Minister for Culture.

    As regards the wording referred to and remarked upon by the Member for Farrer Park - I agree that the wording is not as happy as it could be, but nevertheless I think the intention is fair enough. There is a world of difference, of course, between contributions to cultural associations and the sum of $80,000 allot ted under the vote of the Ministry of Culture. I think I will leave it to my colleague to explain the difference.

    The Chairman: Perhaps he can explain the difference when we come to the item, unless the Member wishes to have the explanation now.

Column: 1006



    Mr Rajah: No. Mr Speaker, Sir, am I to understand from the Minister for Finance that the societies listed in the sub-head: 

          "Children's Concert Fund

           Children's Theatre Fund

           Orchestral Performances  Committee.

            Grant for

           Maintenance of instruments

           Singapore Arts Council"


have not been ruled out but they could apply for allocation from this approximately $25,000 fund? Will they be eligible if they satisfy the Minister?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: That is indeed the position. These associations as well as others could make their cases before the Minister for Culture.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: In view of the explanation, may I beg leave to withdraw the amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $1,315,110 for Head 25 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 1006



    Head 26 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 26 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (18) of sub-head 1.

    Sir, this provision is for the payment of hotel allowances. Although it has been reduced by $20,000 as compared with the 1959 Estimates, I would like to ask the Government whether this vote could not be further reduced in view of the many Government houses that are now vacant.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the provision under this subhead is for payment of hotel expenses for expatriate officers who are preparing to leave the State prior to retirement or on long leave. The maximum stay permitted in a hotel at Government expense is three days, and it covers cost of hotel expenses of the wife and family. As I said, this does not provide for expatriate officers who live in hotels in lieu of occupation of Government quarters.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: May I beg leave to withdraw the amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

Column: 1007



    Head 27-

    The sum of $1,043,870 for Head 26 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 27 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of sub-head 1.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand that the present holder of this post, Comptroller of Customs, is an expatriate officer and that he is about to proceed on retirement, probably on Malayanisation terms - I do not know - but anyway I understand he is leaving the service. I also understand that, instead of making provision or arrangements to have somebody from within the Department promoted to the post of Comptroller of Customs, a person from the Police Force has been brought in with a view to taking over the duties of the Comptroller of Customs and subsequent confirmation.

    Could the Minister please confirm whether my information is correct, and, if it is correct, whether it is desirable that somebody from outside the service should be brought in and made Comptroller of Customs, and whether such a procedure would not tend to discourage serving officers in the Department?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The post of Comptroller of Customs is not due to be malayanised until 1962. So whatever happens to the present incumbent will not affect the immediate position so far as local senior officers are concerned.

    It is true that a senior Police Officer has been seconded to the Customs Department with a view to eventual promotion if he is suitable. This is not an easy decision either for the Government to make or for the officer concerned to accept. I would like to explain to the Member for Farrer Park that the staffing position in the Customs Department, while at present adequate, leaves room for anxiety as to the future. There are five local officers of any seniority in the Customs service, and their years of experience range from four years to eight years. It seems to me that, in such an important Department earning by far the largest single source of revenue to the Government, it would be undesirable to leave matters in the hands of relatively

Column: 1008

junior officers. I wish to make it clear now that I am in no way denigrating their ability, and indeed the present Comptroller of Customs has the highest opinion of the local senior officers in the service.

3.00 p.m.

    But taking into account their youth and the comparative shortness of their experience, I have come to the conclusion that it would be a prudent move to transfer a senior police officer with many years of experience in the service to understudy the Comptroller of Customs for eventual Malayanisation. I do not think that this would lead to any frustration among the local officers, because by and large they are an extremely young group and the police officer concerned is more than middle-aged, and with his maturity of judgment and experience in police investigation methods, I think that when the time comes for the complete Malayanisation of the department (which is due to take place two years from now) we can be more confident that the whole service will stand up to all the tests placed upon it. I have discussed this matter with the Treasury officials and the Comptroller of Customs, and they have agreed with me on the wisdom of this move.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Minister for Finance for his explanation, but I think it is a great pity that somebody from within the department could not be trained to fill this post eventually. Mr Speaker, Sir, the efficiency and adequacy of the department is ultimately in the hands of the Minister and he is the person best qualified to judge it. In view of his explanation, may I be given leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $3,879,280 for Head 27 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 1008



    Head 31-

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker. Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 31 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (11) of sub-head 1.

Column: 1009



    In the Income Tax Department, it is now proposed to have a new post of Deputy Commissioner, Grade G, $1,520 per month. The post of Commissioner is graded in Grade D, $21,240 a year. As far as I can gather, Mr Speaker, Sir, there has been no Deputy to the Commissioner from the time of inauguration of that office up till now. We see from the budget proposals that, so far as income tax increase in collections is concerned, there is none. The position is the same in this year's proposals as in last year's. In view of that, could the Minister please explain why it is necessary to have a Deputy Commissioner of this high grade? If the suggestion is that it is intended by this appointment to accelerate tax collections and ferret out income tax dodgers who otherwise might have remained hidden, he has my whole-hearted support. But it would appear from the income tax proposals that that would not be the position. Is it intended that this post should be filled from within the serving ranks? Is it intended that it should be advertised? Or is it intended that it should be filled by a serving officer who has given efficient, loyal and faithful service to the Government?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Inland Revenue Department is the ultimate result of a reorganisation of the departments of Income Tax, Stamp Office and Estate Duty, and provides for more efficient revenue collecting in a sounder establishment structure. It is therefore necessary to provide this new department with a head. As an economy measure, however, it was decided not to create a new post but to re-title the post of Comptroller of Income Tax. Grade D, as Commissioner of Inland Revenue, Grade D. By this means then the Income Tax Department would be without a head. There were four Assistant Commissioners on the salary scale $1,300-40A-1,420, and the next highest post, therefore, would be a Grade G post. It would be necessary, as I said, to have this extra post to provide the Income Tax Department with its head, although the present Comptroller of Income Tax, as the head of the Inland Revenue Department, would have overall control

Column: 1010

and detailed authority over this department.

    As regards the manner of recruiting an officer for this post, it will follow ordinary and normal establishment practice.

    Mr Rajah: In view of the explanation of the Minister, may I be given leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $1,835,100 for Head 31 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 1010



    Head 34 -

    The following amendment stood in the name of Mr Thio Chan Bee-

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 34 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (3) of sub-head 1. 1.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, since a similar item was previously discussed fully, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    The Chairman: The amendment has not been moved, and therefore there is nothing to withdraw. The hon. Member is not moving.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 34 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (4) of sub-head 2.

    Sir, throughout the Budget, the item "Postage and Telegrams" in every other Ministry has been cut down considerably, and I congratulate the Minister for Finance on the skill with which he has managed that. But in the Ministry of Labour and Law, instead of finding a reduction in conformity with the other Ministries, postages and telegrams have gone up seven times. Does the Minister propose to do seven times the amount of writing that the other Ministries do?

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indeed delighted to know that the Opposition has got over its bogey with Political Secretaries and is leaving them alone for the time being. I had expected to be obliged this afternoon to answer a number of questions on the work of the Ministry of Labour and Law, but I have been reduced to giving explanations on the amount of money we spend on postages, telegrams and diplomatic bags.

Column: 1011



    Mr Speaker, in the past, there used to be a block vote to pay for the cost of diplomatic mail and telegrams despatched on behalf of the various Ministries to the Secretary of State. With the introduction of the new Constitution, these obligations have been taken over by the United Kingdom Commissioner's Office. The Ministry of Finance asked the various Ministries to make a scrutiny of the cost of the various correspondence they had in the past sent to the Office of the Council of Ministers for despatch to the Secretary of State. An inquiry was made, and it was found that, although we did not have detailed figures on the actual cost of telegrams and correspondence that left our Ministry, it was estimated that a provision of $1,400 would meet our needs for next year. I would submit, Mr Speaker, that the Ministry of Labour and Law have not been extravagant in this proposed expenditure. If the Member for Farrer Park wants a breakdown, I can give it to him.

3.15 p.m.

Column: 1011



    Head 36 -

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 36 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 5.

Column: 1012



    Sub-head 5, "Accountant to Official Assignee - $21,240." Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand the situation, so far as the Office of Official Assignee and Public Trustee is concerned, there is attached to it permanently an accountant. Therefore, I am somewhat at a loss to understand why the emoluments of the Accountant to the Official Assignee should be treated as special expenditure. I understood special expenditure to mean expenditure which would be incurred for that year and not for subsequent years. Does it mean that the Official Assignee will only require an accountant for next year, and provision will be sought for 1961 in some other form?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the person in question discharging the duties of Accountant to the Official Assignee is, I think, an expatriate officer on contract. He has been in the service from the 22nd July, 1946. In 1955 he was granted a renewal of his contract for three years. In 1958 the previous Government renewed his contract for another three years. His present contract will expire on 13th December, 1960. He has been a contract officer all along, and there is no hope of his appointment being made permanent. He will be helping out in the Official Assignee's Department for as long as he is wanted, and it is not proposed to extend his contract further than the end of next year.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, as I understand the Minister, the expenditure incurred for the Accountant to the Official Assignee is not an annually recurrent charge. But as far as I can make out, he is an officer who has always been attached to the Official Assignee's Department. In fact that Department cannot do without an Accountant because the work is concerned with bankruptcy, figures and accounting. I am not questioning the payment to this officer. What I would like to know is why it appears as special expenditure and why it has not appeared under annually recurrent expenses? I am not in any way saying that there should not be such an officer. But what I do say is that the office is permanent - it might be held by an expatriate temporarily, but it must be permanent.

Column: 1013



    Mr Byrne: I will see to it, Mr Speaker. We will look into this matter when the officer's contract expires.

    Mr Rajah: In view of the explanation, may I be given leave to withdraw, Mr Speaker, Sir?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

Column: 1013



    Head 37 -

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 37 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (4) of sub-head 1.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been said that one baby is born every eight minutes. The present ratio of population is that 51 per cent of the population are under 21 years, and in 1965, I believe, we are expecting 46 per cent to be under 14. I am quoting this figure just to show that the youth population is increasing very fast. I notice that there is only one Principal Youth Service Officer. There is no increase in that, and I believe that the youth officers are already overburdened with work. With the expansion expected in 1960, will we not need more youth officers?

    Madam Hoe Puay Choo (Bras Basah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, we now know that the Member for Mountbatten is very interested in social welfare work. Why is she so interested in this? If I remember correctly, the Member for Mountbatten was, before the general election, the chairman of a youth club. We can therefore understand why she is interested in social welfare. Originally she was the chairman of a club in Siglap. Why then did she go to Mountbatten to stand for the election?

    The Chairman: Order. I think the hon. Lady must understand that all these personalities, as I have indicated, are completely irrelevant. She is touching on the personal conduct of a Member of the Assembly, and the personal conduct of a Member of the Assembly cannot be discussed except on a substantive motion. I think the Member for Mountbatten

Column: 1014

asked a question about why no provision has been made in the 1960 Estimates for more Principal Youth Service Officers. That is all.

    Madam Hoe Puay Choo(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, the Member, as I mentioned just now, is connected with social welfare work. That is why I said that. We know that under the old society, some of the youths were not organised and so they went astray. Under the new Government, we have to reorganise the old state of affairs. The task of reorganisation has fallen on us. In view of the increase in population, we must know how to organise. Unless we do that, we cannot take full advantage of our available resources. We should think of ways and means to achieve that. We must put a lot of effort and resources into that work. But we must economise. This is our present task.

    We read every day about events concerning secret societies in the newspapers. This is the most immediate task we are faced with at the present moment. These persons were not born to be like that.
